sen.j: 明治末以来、藩閥勢力の代表で陸軍に近い桂太郎（長州藩出身）と立憲政友会の西園寺公望（公家出身）が「情意投合」のもと、交互に政権を担う慣例が続いていた（桂園時代と呼ばれる）。
sen.e: From the end of the Meiji period, it became conventional that the Japanese government alternated between Taro KATSURA, who was closely related to the Japanese Army and came - and represented the interest of the people - from former Choshu Domain, and Kinmochi SAIONJI, who had been a court noble and then belonged to "Rikken Seiyukai Party" (in abbreviation, RSP, a political party organized by Hirobumi ITO), for they had concluded "Joi Togo" (the agreement to take power alternately), and their reign is called Kei-En era after their names.
sen.cmt: （注）・・・「情意投合」につき「(桂と西園寺の間で結ばれた)交互に政権を担う、との合意」と解説しています。
sen.e: From the end of the Meiji period, in the Japanese government a conventional power rotation system was implemented under the agreement called 'Joi Togo' (the agreement to take power alternately) between Taro KATSURA (from the former Choshu Domain), who was closely related to the Japanese Army and a representative figure of the domain-based forces, and Kinmochi SAIONJI (from the former court noble), who belonged to the Rikken Seiyukai (a political party organized by Hirobumi ITO, hereinafter referred to Seiyukai) (called Kei-En era after the initial characters of their names).

sen.j: 明治天皇崩御（死去）直後の1912年12月、第2次西園寺内閣は日露戦争後の財政難から緊縮財政の方針をとり、陸軍の二個師団増設要求を拒んだ。
sen.e: Right after demise of Emperor Meiji in December 1912, the second Saionji Cabinet adopted a policy of austerity because of financial difficulties after Japanese-Russo War, so he rejected the demand from the Japanese Army to increase two army divisions.

Right after the demise of Emperor Meiji in December 1912, the second Saionji Cabinet adopted a policy of austerity because of financial difficulties after the Russo-Japanese War, and rejected the demand from the Japanese Army to increase two army divisions.
sen.cmt: 日露戦争：訳語にthe Japanese-Russo War, Russo-Japanese War の2種類があります。ここでは、Russo-Japanese Warに変えました。
sen.e: Right after the demise of Emperor Meiji in December 1912, the second Saionji Cabinet adopted a policy of austerity because of financial difficulties after the Russo-Japanese War, and rejected the demand from the Japanese Army to increase two army divisions.

sen.j: それに対し、陸軍大臣上原勇作は帷幄上奏権を利用して、単独で即位直後の大正天皇に直接辞表を提出した。
sen.e: In response, Yusaku UEHARA, the Minister of Army, directly handed in his resignation to Emperor Taisho who just ascended to the throne, utilizing "Iaku Joso-ken" (the authority of the Japanese Forces that could directly submit a proposal of military affairs to the emperor without any control of the Diet and the cabinet).
sen.cmt: （注）・・・「帷幄（いあく）上奏権」につき、「日本軍が軍事に関し議会や内閣を経ずに直接天皇に上奏することができた、その権限のこと」と解説しています。

sen.j: 陸軍は後任を送らなかったため、西園寺内閣は総辞職に追いこまれる事態となった。
sen.e: The Japanese Army did not recommend a successor to Uehara, so the whole cabinet of Saionji was forced to resign.
Since the Japanese Army refused to recommend a successor to Uehara, the Saijo Cabinet was forced to resign en masse.

sen.j: 元老会議は後継首相に桂太郎を指名したが、桂は半年前に内大臣兼侍従長になったばかりであり、この点に関して「宮中・府中の別」を乱すものとして非難の声があがった。
sen.e: The conference of elder statesmen designated Taro KATSURA as the next prime minister, but he had assumed both Minister of Palace and Grand Chamberlain just half a year before, so the designation was criticized to be problematic in view of the principle that the Imperial Family and the Japanese government organization could not get involved with each other.
sen.cmt: （注）・・・「宮中・府中の別」については「皇室・皇族関係の組織（宮中）と内閣以下の政府組織（府中）とは、互いに他方に関与できない、との原則」と解説しています。
sen.e: The conference of elder statesmen appointed Taro KATSURA as the next prime minister, but he had already assumed both Minister of Palace and Grand Chamberlain just half a year before, and his nomination became a target for criticism as a violation of the principle of separation between the Imperial Family and the Japanese government organization.

sen.j: また、財政に関心の深い財界からも軍閥の横暴に批判の声が高まった。
sen.e: Japanese business community, which was deeply concerned about the national finance, began to criticize the despotism of the military clique, and the general public got angry about the unconstitutional scheme of the Japanese Army - particularly, Aritomo YAMAGATA's faction - to overthrow the cabinet, and about the repeated candidacy for prime minister of Katsura, who was a politician from the clique of former Choshu Domain, and these triggered the campaign for defending constitutionalism.

sen.j: さらに陸軍（山県閥）による非立憲的な倒閣の策動や藩閥政治家の再出馬に憤る声が広汎に広がって、憲政擁護運動（護憲運動）がはじまった。
sen.e: Moreover, the people's indignation over the unconstitutional politics of the Japanese Army (by Aritomo YAMAGATA's faction) to overthrow the Cabinet and the repeated running for election of the domain-based politicians triggered the Campaign for the Defense of the Constitutionalism (the Campaign for the Defense of the Constitution).

sen.j: 12月13日、東京の新聞記者・弁護士らが憲政振作会を組織して二個師団増設反対を決議し、翌14日には交詢社有志が発起人となって時局懇談会をひらいて、会の名を憲政擁護会とした。
sen.e: On December 13, "Kensei Shinsakukai Party" (a political party organized by journalists and lawyers in Tokyo) made a resolution that it went against the increase of two army divisions, and in the next day, some supporters of "Kojun-sha" (the first social club of businessmen in Japan) assumed promoters of a meeting for discussing the state of affairs, and named it "Kensei Yogokai Meeting" (Meeting for Defending Constitutionalism).

sen.j: 19日の歌舞伎座での憲政擁護第1回大会では、政友会、国民党の代議士や新聞記者のほか実業家や学生も参加し、約3,000の聴衆を集めて「閥族打破、憲政擁護」を決議している。
sen.e: In the first rally of the campaign for defending constitutionalism held at Kabuki-za Theater on December 19, many people took part, such as the Diet members of RSP and "Rikken Kokuminto Party" (Constitutional National Party, and in abbreviation, CNP), journalists, businessmen, students, and the audience of about 3,000, and they made a resolution that cliques should be overthrown and that constitutionalism should be defended.

In the first rally of the Campaign for the Defense of the Constitutionalism held at Kabuki-za Theater on December 19, many people took part, such as the Diet members of the Seiyukai and the Rikken Kokuminto (Constitutional National Party, hereinafter referred to the Kokuminto), journalists, businessmen, students and about 3,000 audiences, and they adopted a resolution that 'cliques should be overthrown and that constitutionalism should be defended.'

sen.j: 12月21日、西園寺内閣が正式に総辞職して第3次桂太郎内閣が発足した。
sen.e: Nevertheless, on December 21, the whole Saionji Cabinet resigned formally, and the third Cabinet of Taro KATSURA started.

sen.e: In response, on December 27, the Diet members in non-government parties, journalists, scholars and others gathered and decided to extend the campaign to local areas.

On the other hand, the Diet members of the opposition parties, journalists, scholars and others had a rally on December 27 and decided to extend the campaign for defending the constitution to other provinces.

sen.j: 翌年1月、「憲政擁護」を叫ぶ大会が各地でひらかれ、日露戦争後の重税に苦しむ商工業者や都市民衆が多数これに参加した。
sen.e: In January the next year, rallies calling for defending constitutionalism were held in many places, in which many people participated, including commerce and industry people and urban residents, who were suffering from heavy tax after Japanese-Russo War.

sen.j: 21日、議会の開会予定をさらに15日間停会した桂内閣の処置により、かえって運動は加熱し、24日の東京での憲政擁護第2回大会はじめ、運動は全国的なひろがりをみせて一大国民運動となっていった。
sen.e: Seeing this, the Katsura Cabinet postponed on January 21 the opening day of the Diet until 15 days later, but this only poured oil on the flames, so the second rally of the campaign for defending constitutionalism was held in Tokyo on January 24, and the campaign became a big, nationwide movement.

sen.j: こうした動きに対し、桂首相は明治天皇の諒闇中（服喪期間）であるから政争を中止するように諭した大正天皇の詔勅（優詔）を受けてこれを乱発し、政府批判を封じた（優詔政策）。
sen.e: Against this movement, Prime Miniter Katsura frequently cited "Shochoku" (an imperial edict) of Emperor Taisho, which dissuaded people from getting involved in political disputes because it was still in the period for mourning former Emperor Meiji, thereby silencing criticism against the government - and this Katsura's way is called Imperial Edict Tactics.

Against this movement, Prime Minister Katsura frequently abused "Shochoku" (imperial edict) of Emperor Taisho, which was originally issued by the Emperor to stop the political disputes, respecting the period for mourning of former Emperor Meiji (Imperial Edict Tactics), and tried to silence the people's criticism of the government.

sen.j: この間、立憲政友会と立憲国民党の提携が成立し、とくに立憲政友会党員の尾崎行雄や立憲国民党党首の犬養毅が中心となって活躍した。

sen.e: On February 5, at the reconvened Diet, non-government parties, including RSP and CNP, put forward a non-confidence motion against the cabinet, and the Diet adjourned immediately.

sen.j: 大正政変は、山縣有朋・桂率いる陸軍・長州閥が第2次西園寺内閣を倒閣し、これに反対する民衆運動が政党組織や優詔政策といった小手先の政策で交わそうとする「閥族内閣」を打倒したというイメージが強い。
sen.e: "Taisho Seihen" has a strong image that the clique of the Japanese Army and former Choshu Domain, led by Aritomo YAMAGATA and Taro KATSURA, overthrew the second Saionji Cabinet, and that the demonstration of masses against it toppled the party organization and the clique-ruling cabinet, which took makeshift measures, such as Imperial Edict Tactics.

The typical image of the Taisho Seihen is the public movement that toppled the 'clique-ruling Cabinet' formed by the Japanese Army and the former Choshu Domain clique, led by Aritomo YAMAGATA and Taro KATSURA respectively, because the public took objection to the Cabinet which, after overthrowing of the second Saionji Cabinet, tried to silence the public voices by fiddling measures such as the party politics and the Imperial Edict Tactics.

The typical image of the Taisho Seihen is the public movement that toppled the 'clique-ruling Cabinet' formed by the Japanese Army and the former Choshu Domain clique, led by Aritomo YAMAGATA and Taro KATSURA respectively, because the public took objection to the Cabinet which, after overthrowing of the second Saionji Cabinet, tried to silence the public voices by fiddling measures such as the party politics and the Imperial Edict Tactics.

sen.j: しかし、大正政変を経て誕生した「桂新党」（立憲同志会→憲政会）は立憲政友会とともに政党政治をリードすることになる立憲民政党の前身である。
sen.e: However, Katsura New Party (in abbreviation, KNP) established after "Taisho Seihen" was the forerunner of "Rikken Minseito Party" (Party of Dmocratic Constitutionalism), which would lead party politics along with RSP, and incidentally, KNP later became "Rikken Doshikai Party" (Party of Comrades of Constitutionalism, and in abbreviation, PCC) and then "Kenseikai Party" (Party of Constitutionalism, and inabbreviation, PC).
sen.cmt: （注）・・・原文の、「（立憲同志会→憲政会）」の部分は、英文では後半に持ってきています。
sen.e: However, it should be noted that the 'Katsura Shinto' (Katsura New Party) established after the period of Taisho Seihen was the forerunner of the Rikken Minseito (Party of Democratic Constitutionalism), which would lead party politics along with the Seiyukai (later, Katsura Shinto was developed into the Rikken Doshikai [Party of Comrades of Constitutionalism] and then into the Kenseikai [Party of Constitutionalism]).
sen.cmt: 政党名の省略をもとに戻しました。原文にない " "を取りました。

sen.j: 一方、山縣は政党を敵視し続けた。
sen.e: Meanwhile, Yamagata continued to be hostile to political parties.
Meanwhile, Yamagata continued to be hostile to political parties.
Meanwhile, Yamagata continued to be hostile to political parties.

sen.j: 桂と山縣とをひとくくりにして大正政変を論じることはできない。
sen.e: Therefore, we cannot lump Katsura and Yamagata together when discussing "Taisho Seihen."
Therefore, we cannot lump the policies of Katsura and Yamagata together when discussing the Taisho Seihen.
Therefore, we cannot lump the policies of Katsura and Yamagata together when discussing the Taisho Seihen.

sen.j: 2度の内閣を組織し、明治天皇から強い信頼を得ていた桂太郎は、「桂新党」の設立と山県系官僚閥を改革する新政策を模索していた。
sen.e: Taro KATSURA, who had led the Japanese government twice and won the strong trust of Emperor Meiji, sought to establish KNP and to reform the clique of bureaucrats connected with Yamagata.

Taro KATSURA, who led the Japanese government twice and won the strong trust of Emperor Meiji, sought to establish a new party 'Katsura Shinto' and reform the clique of bureaucrats connected with Yamagata.

Taro KATSURA, who led the Japanese government twice and won the strong trust of Emperor Meiji, sought to establish a new party 'Katsura Shinto' and reform the clique of bureaucrats connected with Yamagata.

sen.j: これは、自ら結成した新党を政権基盤とする政権を樹立し、政友会への依存からの脱却と山縣からの自立を企図するものであった。
sen.e: Katsura comtemplated establishing his administration anew, based on the party of his own, thereby freeing himself from dependence on RSP and on Yamagata.
Katsura contemplated establishing his new administration based on the party of his own, and thereby freeing himself from the dependence on the Seiyukai and on Yamagata.
Katsura contemplated establishing his new administration based on the party of his own, and thereby freeing himself from the dependence on the Seiyukai and on Yamagata.

sen.j: それを察知した山縣は、明治天皇崩御（死去）直後の1912年8月に桂を内大臣兼侍従長に押し込めて政治的引退を図る。
sen.e: Swiftly seeing through Katsura's intention, Yamagata forced Katsura into honorary posts of Minister of Palace and Grand Chamberlain in August 1912 right after demise of Emperor Meiji, thereby trying to deprive him of real political power.
sen.cmt: （注）・・・「政治的引退を図る」の部分は、「（名誉職に押し込めて）政治的実権を奪おうとした」の意味に解しています。
sen.e: Swiftly detecting Katsura's attempt, Yamagata forced Katsura to hold the two honorary posts, the minister of palace and the grand chamberlain in August 1912, right after the demise of Emperor Meiji, trying to deprive Katsura of real political power.

sen.e: Swiftly detecting Katsura's attempt, Yamagata forced Katsura to hold the two honorary posts, the minister of palace and the grand chamberlain in August 1912, right after the demise of Emperor Meiji, trying to deprive Katsura of real political power.

sen.j: 一方の西園寺も、政友会の党務を事実上取り仕切り、地方利益の追求をすすめる原敬との確執を強めていた。
sen.e: On the other hand, Saionji fiercely conflicted with Takashi HARA, who was substantially controlling party business of RSP and was pursuing interests of local areas.
On the other hand, Saionji was intensifying feud with Takashi HARA, who was practically controlling the affaires of the Seiyukai and pursuing local interests.

sen.j: そもそも増師問題は、当初は陸軍・政友会間での妥協が図られていた。
sen.e: In the first place, the Japanese Army and RSP were near to a compromise on the issue of increase of two army divisions, but Katsura, who regarded the issue as a good chance to return to the government, and the clique of former Satsuma Domain, which was away from power in the midst of Kei-En era, both tried to take advantage of it, and made Uehara take the hard line, and this complicated the issue.
In the first place, the Japanese Army and the Seiyukai were seeking a compromise on the increase of two army divisions.

sen.j: だが、これを政権復帰の好機と見た桂・「桂園時代」により政権から遠ざかっていた薩摩閥両者の思惑が上原を強硬な態度へ導いたことで大きな問題となったのである。
sen.e: However, Katsura, who regarded the situation as an opportunity for him to return to the government, and the Satsuma clique, which had been swept away from power during the Kei-En era, set out to take advantage of this situation and obliged Uehara (the minister of army) to take the hard line, provoking serious repercussions.

sen.j: 事態の急変に対して山縣は、内閣と陸軍を調停する優詔を起案したが桂により握りつぶされる。
sen.e: Seeing a sudden turn of a political situation, Yamagata prepared a draft of an imperial edict to mediate between the Saionji Cabinet and the Japanese Army, but Katsura crushed the draft.
Seeing a sudden turn of the political situation, Yamagata prepared a draft of an imperial edict to mediate an accord between the Saionji Cabinet and the Japanese Army, but Katsura crushed the draft.

sen.e: Seeing a sudden turn of the political situation, Yamagata prepared a draft of an imperial edict to mediate an accord between the Saionji Cabinet and the Japanese Army, but Katsura crushed the draft.

sen.j: 体調不良と原との確執により既に政権続行への意欲を失っていた西園寺と、桂との会見で山縣の真意が倒閣にあると曲解した原は、内閣総辞職を決断、「山縣の手による倒閣」が成功する。
sen.e: Saionji had already lost his will to keep his administration for his poor physical condition and the conflict with Hara, and Hara misunderstood in his meeting with Katsura that Yamagata's real intention was to topple the Saionji Cabinet, so Saionji and Hara decided to implement the cabinet resignation en masse, and therefore, this seemingly resulted from Yamagata's maneuver.

The then Prime Minister Saionji, who had already lost his zeal to keep his administration, suffering from not only his poor physical condition but also from the conflict with Hara, and Hara, who misunderstood that Yamagata's real intention was to topple the Saionji Cabinet in the meeting held with Katsura, decided the Cabinet resignation en masse, and in this way, the 'Cabinet turnover by Yamagata's maneuver' was achieved.

The then Prime Minister Saionji, who had already lost his zeal to keep his administration, suffering from not only his poor physical condition but also from the conflict with Hara, and Hara, who misunderstood that Yamagata's real intention was to topple the Saionji Cabinet in the meeting held with Katsura, decided the Cabinet resignation en masse, and in this way, the 'Cabinet turnover by Yamagata's maneuver' was achieved.

sen.j: 後継首相の選定は、薩摩閥の推す松方正義が高齢を理由に辞退、同じく薩摩閥の山本権兵衛、山県閥の平田東助が政権運営の困難を理由に辞退したことで混迷し、大命は桂に降ることとなった。
sen.e: The successor to the prime minister was not decided soon, for some candidates declined to assume it - Masayoshi MATSUKATA, recommended by the clique of former Satsuma Domain, declined for his old age, and Gonbei YAMAMOTO, also recommended by Satsuma clique, and Tosuke HIRATA, who belonged to Yamagata faction, both declined for anticipated difficulties to manage the administration - so an Imperial command to form a cabinet was issued to Katsura in the end.

Selection of the successor to the prime minister was complicated due to the successive declines to assume the post; Masayoshi MATSUKATA, recommended by the Satsuma clique, declined it for his old age, and Gonbei YAMAMOTO of the Satsuma clique and Tosuke HIRATA of the Yamagata faction declined it for the anticipated difficulties to manage the administration, and in the end the Imperial command was issued to Katsura to form a Cabinet.
sen.cmt: 表現を若干変えました。
sen.e: Selection of the successor to the prime minister was complicated due to the successive declines to assume the post; Masayoshi MATSUKATA, recommended by the Satsuma clique, declined it for his old age, and Gonbei YAMAMOTO of the Satsuma clique and Tosuke HIRATA of the Yamagata faction declined it for the anticipated difficulties to manage the administration, and in the end the Imperial command was issued to Katsura to form a Cabinet.

sen.j: 桂は斎藤実海相を優詔により留任させると、若槻禮次郎、後藤新平ら自前の官僚勢力、イギリス流政治を信奉する加藤高明（駐英大使）を入閣させて自前の内閣を組織している。
sen.e: Katsura organized his cabinet in his own way through making Makoto SAITO, the Minister of the Navy, stay in office with the help of an imperial edict, and bringing some people of his choice into his cabinet, such as Reijiro WAKATSUKI and Shinpei GOTO, both bureaucrats, and Takaaki KATO, Japanese Ambassador to Britain, who espoused British politics.

Katsura organized his Cabinet in his own way by making Makoto SAITO, the minister of the Navy in the former Cabinet, stay in office with the help of an Imperial edict, and inviting some bureaucrats of his influence, such as Reijiro WAKATSUKI and Shinpei GOTO, as well as the espouser of British politics, Takaaki KATO (Japanese Ambassador to Britain).
sen.cmt: 表現を若干変えました。
sen.e: Katsura organized his Cabinet in his own way by making Makoto SAITO, the minister of the Navy in the former Cabinet, stay in office with the help of an Imperial edict, and inviting some bureaucrats of his influence, such as Reijiro WAKATSUKI and Shinpei GOTO, as well as the espouser of British politics, Takaaki KATO (Japanese Ambassador to Britain).

sen.j: 桂の新政策とその意欲の一方で、優詔政策の失敗など護憲運動への対応の迷走、政友会との決定的な対立、貴族院工作の失敗、山縣・寺内正毅ら陸軍内部からの不信が桂を追いつめていくことになる。
sen.e: Katsura implemented new policies in earnest, while he failed in his Imperial Edict Tactics and other countermeasures against the campaign for defending constitutionalism, caused a fierce conflict with RSP, failed in political maneuvering of the House of Peers, and earned distrust from Aritomo YAMAGATA, Masatake TERAUCHI, and other people in the Japanese Army, so he would be driven into a corner.

Although Katsura implemented new policies in earnest, a series of blunders in his politics, such as the failure in his Imperial Edict Tactics and countermeasures against the Campaign for the Defense of the Constitution, fierce conflict with the Seiyukai, failure in political maneuvering of the House of Peers, and a growing distrust of him among the people of the Japanese Army including Aritomo YAMAGATA and Masatake TERAUCHI, drove him into a corner.
sen.cmt: 表現を若干変えました。
sen.e: Although Katsura implemented new policies in earnest, a series of blunders in his politics, such as the failure in his Imperial Edict Tactics and countermeasures against the Campaign for the Defense of the Constitution, fierce conflict with the Seiyukai, failure in political maneuvering of the House of Peers, and a growing distrust of him among the people of the Japanese Army including Aritomo YAMAGATA and Masatake TERAUCHI, drove him into a corner.

sen.j: 大正政変は藩閥勢力に大打撃を与えるとともに、政権担当能力を有する第二党の成長も出遅らせることとなった。
sen.e: "Taisho Seihen" dealt a huge blow to the cliques of former domains, and it also held back the development of an alternative to the party in power.
Taisho Seihen not only gave a huge blow to the domain-based cliques, but also caused a stagnation in the development of an alternative to the party in power.
sen.cmt: 表現を若干変えました。
sen.e: Taisho Seihen not only gave a huge blow to the domain-based cliques, but also caused a stagnation in the development of an alternative to the party in power.

sen.j: また、西園寺は「違勅」（政争を辞めるようにとの天皇の「優詔」に違反した罪）を盾に政友会総裁の辞任を表明する。
sen.e: Saionji announced his resignation from the leader of RSP by reason of "breaking the edict" (breaking the imperial edict to stop political disputes).

Saionji announced his resignation from the presidency of the Seiyukai with the pretext that 'he violated the edict' (it was his fault that he was not able to stop political disputes following the imperial edict).
sen.cmt: 表現を若干変えました。RSP →the Seiyukai
sen.e: Saionji announced his resignation from the presidency of the Seiyukai with the pretext that 'he violated the edict' (it was his fault that he was not able to stop political disputes following the imperial edict).

sen.j: 桂が出させたものであるとはいえ、「公家は天皇の藩屏でなければならない」と信じる西園寺にとって、自分が率いる政友会が天皇の詔勅を無視したことは許されないという論理である。
sen.e: Though Katsura made him say so, Saionji himself thought he was unforgivable for his own leading RSP's neglect of the edict, because Saionji believed that former court nobles should be "hanpei" (protectors of the emperor) even after the Meiji Restoration.

Although it was a forced announcement by Katsura, Saionji, who believed that former court nobles should be 'hanpei' (protectors of the emperor) even after the Meiji Restoration, insisted that he himself was responsible and unforgivable as the leader of the party for the Seiyukai's neglect of the edict.
sen.cmt: 「桂が出させたものであるとはいえ」の意味は「西園寺のこの辞任表明は桂が出させたもの…」という意味で良いか不明です。

sen.j: 政友会の幹部達はこの「違勅」の論理に困惑したが、西園寺の決意は揺らぐことが無かった。
sen.e: Senior members of RSP were puzzled with this logic of breaking the edict, but Saionji's determination was never shaken.
Senior members of the RSP were puzzled with this logic of 'violation of the edict,' but Saionji's decision was firm.

sen.j: 西園寺が後継に指名した松田正久の死去により、後継総裁に原敬が就任して立憲政友会は新たな段階へと進むことになる。
sen.e: Saionji designated Masahisa MATSUDA as his successor, but Matsuda died suddenly, so Takashi HARA assumed the leader of RSP, and this opened a new stage for the party.
Although Saionji firstly appointed Masahisa MATSUDA as his successor, Matsuda died suddenly, and the RSP presidency was assumed by Takashi HARA and the party stepped forward to a new stage.

sen.j: 日比谷焼打事件でも示された民衆運動の力がついに政権を覆した。
sen.e: A popular movement, seen also in the Hibiya riots of 1905, eventually had the power to topple the government in "Taisho Seihen."
A popular movement, the power of which was once exercised in the Hibiya riots of 1905, eventually toppled the government in the Taisho Seihen.

sen.e: A popular movement, the power of which was once exercised in the Hibiya riots of 1905, eventually toppled the government in the Taisho Seihen.

sen.j: 民衆の直接行動が内閣を倒した最初の事例である。
sen.e: It was for the first time in Japanese history that direct action of the masses toppled the government.
It was for the first time in Japanese history that a direct action by the public overthrew the administration.
sen.cmt: 表現を若干変えました。
sen.e: It was for the first time in Japanese history that a direct action by the public overthrew the administration.

sen.j: 藩閥政治の行き詰まりと民主政治の高まりを示すこととなり、これ以後、普選運動など大正デモクラシーの流れをつくっていった。
sen.e: Showing the dead end of clique politics and the growth of democracy, "Taisho Seihen" set the trend for Taisho Democracy, as was seen in a movement for universal manhood suffrage.
sen.cmt: （注）・・・「普選運動」とありますが、「成年男性の普通選挙権」に限られていたので、"manhood"を"suffrage"の前に入れています。
sen.e: Taisho Seihen that caused the dead end of the clique politics and the growth of democracy generated a momentum for Taisho Democracy including the approval of the Universal Manhood Suffrage.
sen.cmt: 普選運動：the approval of the Universal Manhood Suffrage（訳者のコメント参照ください)としました。
sen.e: Taisho Seihen that caused the dead end of the clique politics and the growth of democracy generated a momentum for Taisho Democracy including the approval of the Universal Manhood Suffrage.

sen.j: 松尾尊兌は、ここに始まる大正デモクラシーが一部の都市知識人による脆弱な輸入思想ではなく，戦後民主主義に直結する性質を有する、広汎な民衆運動であったことを説いている。
sen.e: Takayoshi MATSUO (a Japanese historian) says that Taisho Democracy, originating from here, was not the foreign idea superficially scooped by some intellectuals dwelling in a city but the widespread popular movement that was directly linked with the Japanese democracy after World War Ⅱ.

Takayoshi MATSUO (a Japanese historian) argues that Taisho Democracy, starting with the Taisho Seihen, was not a vulnerable foreign idea superficially scooped by some urban intellectuals but a widespread popular movement that had some characteristic directly reflected in the Japanese democracy after World War Ⅱ.

sen.e: Takayoshi MATSUO (a Japanese historian) argues that Taisho Democracy, starting with the Taisho Seihen, was not a vulnerable foreign idea superficially scooped by some urban intellectuals but a widespread popular movement that had some characteristic directly reflected in the Japanese democracy after World War Ⅱ.

sen.j: 1913年1月、護憲運動のさなか、桂は立憲政友会に対抗するため、自ら政党を結成した（桂新党）。
sen.e: In January 1913, amid the movement for defending constitutionalism, Katsura established his own party (KNP) to compete with RSP.
In January 1913, amid the Campaign for the Defense of the Constitution, Katsura established his own party (Katsura Shinto) to compete with the Seiyukai.
In January 1913, amid the Campaign for the Defense of the Constitution, Katsura established his own party (Katsura Shinto) to compete with the Seiyukai.

sen.j: 2月に桂内閣は倒れ、その年の10月に桂も死去するが、これが立憲同志会、のちの憲政会となった。
sen.e: In February, the Katsura Cabinet fell, and in October, Katsura died, but his party KNP was reorganized as PCC, which later became PC.
In February, the Katsura Cabinet fell, and in October, Katsura died, but his party was reorganized as the Rikken Doshikai, which was further developed into the Kenseikai.

sen.j: 桂退陣後に成立した第1次山本内閣は、立憲政友会を与党とし、原敬（内相）や高橋是清（蔵相）ら政友会の有力者を閣僚としてむかえた。
sen.e: The first Yamamoto Cabinet, established after Katsura's, still regarded RSP as the administration party, and brought some influential members of RSP into itself, such as Takashi HARA (as the Minister for Home Affairs) and Korekiyo TAKAHASHI (as the Minister of Finance).

The first Yamamoto Cabinet, established immediately after Katsura's resignation, invited some influential members of the Seiyukai to be the ministers of his administration, such as Takashi HARA (as the minister for home affairs) and Korekiyo TAKAHASHI (as the minister of finance).
sen.cmt: 表現を若干変えました。RSP→the Seiyukai
sen.e: The first Yamamoto Cabinet, established immediately after Katsura's resignation, invited some influential members of the Seiyukai to be the ministers of his administration, such as Takashi HARA (as the minister for home affairs) and Korekiyo TAKAHASHI (as the minister of finance).

sen.j: 山本は世論を怖れて、桂の二の舞を踏むことを避け、軍部大臣現役武官制を緩和して予備役・後備役でも可とし、政党勢力に譲歩するなど、国民に対して融和的な政治をとることで政局の安定化を図った。
sen.e: Being afraid of the public sentiment, Yamamoto tried to avoid making the same mistake as Katsura by taking appeasement policy to the Japanese people, such as relaxing the principle that ministers of the Army and Navy should be active duty officers, by which a first reservist or a second reservist could assume the position, and making a compromise with political parties, thereby stabilizing the political situation.
sen.cmt: （注）・・・原文後半にある「融和的」は「宥和的」の誤りと解されますので、そのように訂正して訳しています。
sen.e: Being nerves of the public sentiment, Yamamoto tried to avoid the same mistake as Katsura and made efforts to stabilize the political situation by taking appeasement policy to the public, such as the moderation of the principle that ministers of the Army and Navy should be active duty officers by admitting a first reservist or a second reservist, and the compromising deals with political parties.
sen.cmt: 表現を若干変えました。
sen.e: Afraid of public sentiment, Yamamoto tried to avoid making the same mistake as Katsura by working to stabilize the political situation; he attempted to do this by taking his appeasement policy to the public—which included principles such as the relaxation of the requirement that ministers of the army and navy should be active duty officers by allowing first reservists or second reservists to hold the positions—and seeking to reach compromising deals with the other political parties.

sen.j: 一方、第1次山本内閣への入閣という形で利益を得る事になった立憲政友会に対して、国民はもちろんの事、立憲国民党や政友会内部からも反発が噴出して尾崎行雄は岡崎邦輔らとともに政友会を離党する（岡崎は後に復党するが、尾崎はそのまま中正会を結党した）。
sen.e: On the other hand, RSP had the benefit of gaining the minister posts in the first Yamamoto Cabinet, which enraged not only the general public but also CNP and RSP members, so some of them, including Yukio OZAKI and Kunisuke OKAZAKI, left RSP; later, Okazaki returned to RSP, but Ozaki newly established "Chuseikai Party" (in abbreviation, CP)

On the other hand, the Seiyukai was benefited by gaining the ministerial posts in the first Yamamoto Cabinet, which enraged not only the general public but also the Rikken Kokuminto members, and even some of the Seiyukai members including Yukio OZAKI, who resented it and left the Seiyukai together with Kunisuke OKAZAKI (although Okazaki returned to the Seiyukai later, Ozaki established a new party 'Chuseikai' [Centrist Justice Party]).

sen.e: On the other hand, the Seiyukai was benefited by gaining the ministerial posts in the first Yamamoto Cabinet, which enraged not only the general public but also the Rikken Kokuminto members, and even some of the Seiyukai members including Yukio OZAKI, who resented it and left the Seiyukai together with Kunisuke OKAZAKI (although Okazaki returned to the Seiyukai later, Ozaki established a new party 'Chuseikai' [Centrist Justice Party]).

sen.j: 政友会は議会での孤立と党首不在という2つの非常事態に陥った。
sen.e: And this drove RSP into a state of emergency, that is, isolation in the Diet and nonexistence of its leader.
And this internal unrest drove the Seiyukai into a state of emergency, in which the party had to suffer the isolation in the Diet and the lack of its leader.

tit.e: Taisho Seihen in a broad sense
Taisho Seihen in a broad sense

sen.j: 冒頭に示した通り、大正政変の時期には広狭二義ある。
sen.e: As is shown in the head of this section, "Taisho Seihen" has two types in its period.
As is pointed out initially, the period of 'Taisho Seihen' is defined in two senses, a broad sense and a narrow sense.
sen.cmt: 広狭：訳漏れ:a broad sense and a narrow sense
sen.e: As is pointed out initially, the period of 'Taisho Seihen' is defined in two senses, a broad sense and a narrow sense.

sen.j: 第1次山本内閣の時代を含めることにより、この時期の民衆が一方では憲政擁護運動以来の反閥族感情を保ちながらも、他方では1913年7月の辛亥革命の混乱に際しては、革命派擁護を名目とする対中出兵論に容易に乗るような大正デモクラーの一側面が視野にはいってくる。
sen.e: By including the era of the first Yamamoto Cabinet into "Taisho Seihen," we can notice that the masses of this period not only held the anti-clique sentiment from the start of the campaign for defending institutionalism but also agreed easily on dispatching troops to China in the name of supporting the revolutionary group amid the turmoil of the Republican Revolution in China in July 1913, and the latter shows us the dark side of Taisho Democracy.

By including the era of the first Yamamoto Cabinet into the Taisho Seihen, we can see another side of Taisho Democracy; since the out set of the Campaign for the Defense of the Constitutionalism, the public in this period retained the anti-clique sentiment, however on the other hand, they easily agreed on dispatching troops to China in the name of supporting the revolutionary group in the turmoil of the Republican Revolution when it broke out in China in July 1913.
sen.cmt: 表現を若干変えました。
sen.e: By including the era of the first Yamamoto Cabinet into the Taisho Seihen, we can see another side of Taisho Democracy; since the out set of the Campaign for the Defense of the Constitutionalism, the public in this period retained the anti-clique sentiment, however on the other hand, they easily agreed on dispatching troops to China in the name of supporting the revolutionary group in the turmoil of the Republican Revolution when it broke out in China in July 1913.

sen.j: 松尾尊兌はこれを「内には立憲主義、外には帝国主義」という二面性をもったものとして説明している。
sen.e: Takayoshi MATSUO explains such two-sidedness of Taisho Democracy with the phrase, "Constitutionalism inside, and imperialism outside."
Takayoshi MATSUO explains such two-sidedness of Taisho Democracy with the phrase, 'inward constitutionalism, and outward imperialism.'

sen.e: Takayoshi MATSUO explains such two-sidedness of Taisho Democracy with the phrase, 'inward constitutionalism, and outward imperialism.'

sen.j: シーメンス事件によって第1次山本内閣が倒れたのち、民衆に人気のある大隈重信が立憲同志会、大隈伯後援会および中正会を与党として2回目の組閣をおこなった。
sen.e: After the Siemens Incident of 1914 blew off the first Yamamoto Cabinet, a popular politician Shigenobu OKUMA formed his second cabinet as a coalition of PCC, Supporters' Association of Count Okuma, and CP.

sen.j: ここでは山東半島におけるドイツ帝国勢力の駆逐と中国利権の確保を契機として、政友会と国民党は選挙で敗北した。
sen.e: Okuma Cabinet ousted forces of the German Empire from Shandong Peninsula and secured the interests of Japan there, and after this, RSP and CNP were defeated in election, the bill to increase two army divisions passed the Diet, and 21 Demands made by Japan to China, which would later stir up the Chinese nationalism, won the approval of the Japanese people.

sen.j: 陸軍二個師団増設が議会を通過し、のちに中国人のナショナリズムをおおいに刺激することになる「対華21か条要求」が国民的承認をうけるのであった。
sen.e: The bill to increase two army divisions passed the Diet, and the '21 Demands' made by Japan to China, which would later stir up the Chinese nationalism, won the approval of the Japanese people.
